node.title: Generating cracks in moose for phase field mehtod using gmsh
node.bodyText:
I have attached an image(ideal crack). How can i generate a crack like this in moose or using gmsh for my phase field applications. When i try by using side set generator and using dirichlet boundary condition of the phase field variable in that region equal to one, the crack is never smooth and i don't get correct load vs reaction graphs for Miehe Tension test. The second image is how i generate a crack.
Please guide how to model a crack in moose correctly

Hello
You can assign different subdomain to the top and bottom part of the mesh
then use the BreakMeshByBlockGenerator to split the mesh.
The "Break"Mesh generators are generally meant for this purpose
Guillaume

node.title: Tutorial 1 not outputting pressure values in exodus file
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hi everyone,
I recently installed moose on my machine. I'm running Windows 11, so I installed WSL and Ubuntu 20.04, as instructed. Then I git cloned the library this morning and have been working to reproduce the first tutorial, babbler.
I'm following the first tutorial exactly so far, except I never linked my code to github, which I imagine wouldn't affect anything. I made the pressure_diffusion.i file exactly the same as in the tutorial as well. I then run
cd ~/projects/babbler/problems
../babbler-opt -i pressure_diffusion.i

and get my 'pressure_diffusion_out.e' file. But when I plot it in ParaView, all pressure values are zero.
The weird thing is that I can run the first example, and I get a correct diffusion gradient.
Not sure what is going on. Does anyone have ideas I could try? Thank you.
Diagnostics for MOOSE installation issues
[Optional] Output of the diagnostics scripts. To run the script: cd ~/projects/moose/scripts; ./diagnostics.sh

Hello
Did you make sure to visualize the second time step and not the initial condition?
Guillaume
Hi Guillaume - thank you so much. I just did that and it worked. I will not be making that mistake again lol

node.title: Calling functions from base class in template class compiles with gcc but not clang
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I recently created a template material class SATauMaterial in the Moltres app that primarily inherits from another template material class INSADTauMaterial.
The app compiles without errors on Linux machines, but encounters the following error on MacOS machines:
error: 'adCoupledValue' following the 'template' keyword does not refer to a template
    _mu_tilde(this->template adCoupledValue("mu_tilde")),

for adCoupledValue and a couple of other functions prefixed with this->template. Full error log
I could only get as far as identifying that this error arises from differences in supported features between gcc and clang. I appreciate any help with this compile error.

Is your new class a template?
Why are you using this->template for these calls?
They are not templates so you can just call the routine directly with no "this->template"
Yes it is also a template SATauMaterialTempl

I thought this->template was for using templated routines within a templated class. I may be wrong.
If I am not, then adCoupledValue is a not a template so no need for these extra qualifiers
You are right. I removed this->template for non-template calls and added using Coupleable::... Thanks for your help!

node.title: Second order time derivatives (no elasticity)!
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello,
I have searched quite a bit and cannot find any simple example of adding a time kernel of d^2u/dt^2 where u is an arbitrary Variable. I seem to remember it was just sitting in framework/src/kernels or maybe in tensor mechanics many years ago.
I found numerous examples of Newmark and CentralDifference dynamics in the solid mechanics.  From what I understand, all of the dynamic elastic problems compute Newmark vel and accel variables and then provide them to the InertialForce Kernel which is linear in the acceleration of the displacements.
Is this the procedure now in general for a non-elastic variable?
First compute its Newmark acceleration, provide a Kernel linear in the acceleration, and then choose Newmark or CentralDiff time integration? Is it possible just to use InertialForce here (say variable = u)? There are no examples of this in the docs or tests so I have to ask. I would go and try this before posting but I am away from the MOOSEing equipment at the moment.
I did find VectorSecondTimeDerivative in the EM module but that is for a VectorVariable which I do not have and rather confused if that also can just accept regular Variables instead. I do know that all of the dotdot_u exist in the coupleable interface but just thought I would check if there is something already ready to go
Please advise! Thanks!
John

No idea. I'd venture it was only used by the mechanics folks who introduced their own time integrator and did all the work there
We can add it. Thanks for sharing the code. Feel free to make a pull request if you want credit for it (as a minor feature, see authorship guidelines)

Quite funny that this compiles with MOOSE cloned two days ago and yet a fresh compile today it does not.
/home/ferret/src/kernels/SecondTimeDerivativeScaled.C:43:2: error: 'uDotDotRequested' was not declared in this scope
   43 |  uDotDotRequested() = true;

Removing this line and it compiles and runs just fine.

I think this is a routine on the problem?
Not something in the transientInterface

node.title: Finding computeQpOffDiagJacobian for sink and recombination

node.bodyText:
Hello

((*_prop_hm[n])[_qp] * (*_prop_kiv[n]) (*_prop_Rho[n])[_qp] * (*_prop_Rhos[n])[_qp] + (*_prop_hm[n])[_qp] * (*_prop_kxs[n]) * (*_prop_Rho[n])[_qp];)

what is n here? I see _qp (which seems correct) in your kernel
For the Jacobian:

do only rho and rho_s depend on variable v? h_m, k_iv and k_vs do not?

For the off-diagonal

does only h-m depend on eta? rho,rho_s and k_vs do not?
I would expect an if-condition there, checking for jvar = index for eta


p.s. Am I missing an override anywhere?

All of these should be override. The nice thing about override is that if you made a mistake in the signature (for example the return type), it wont compile thanks to override
  virtual void initialSetup();

protected:
  virtual Real computeQpResidual();
  virtual Real computeQpJacobian();
  virtual Real computeQpOffDiagJacobian(unsigned int jvar);

NB: do not forget to check your Jacobian with the Jacobian testing tools in MOOSE. See JacobianTest on the website, or troubleshooting failed solves

Thank you so much for your help, the [n] was a mistake as I used CoupledSwitchingTimeDirivative as a template and it inputted multiple values for each and I didnt notice I was pasting an old version of the equation. Here is the updated one:

Real
GrandPotentialSink::computeQpResidual()
{
  return _prop_hm[_qp] * _prop_kiv[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp] * _prop_Rhos[_qp] + _prop_hm[_qp] * _prop_kxs[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp];
}


For the Jacobian:
Yes, only rho and rho_s depend on variable v and they are DerivativeParsedMaterials, here is what they look like in my input file:

[./rhovbub]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    args = 'wv'
    f_name = rhovbub
    material_property_names = 'Va kvbub cvbubeq'
    function = 'wv/Va^2/kvbub + cvbubeq/Va'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./rhovmatrix]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    args = 'wv'
    f_name = rhovmatrix
    material_property_names = 'Va kvmatrix cvmatrixeq'
    function = 'wv/Va^2/kvmatrix + cvmatrixeq/Va'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./rhov]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    args = 'wv'
    f_name = rhov
    material_property_names = 'hm hb rhovmatrix(wv) rhovbub(wv)'
    function = 'hm * rhovmatrix + hb * rhovbub'
    derivative_order = 2
    output_properties = 'rhov'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

K_iv and K_vs are thankfully constants and not dependent on either eta or v.
h_m is a SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial and is dependant on eta.
  [./hm]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    h_name = hm
    all_etas = 'etab0 etam0'
    phase_etas = 'etam0'
  [../]

If those are the only variables that effect it, the above Jacobian should be correct right?

Yes, eta is the only variable effecting h_m as seen above. I added the if statement but I am still confused on what the offdiagjaacobina should look like. I have been following both beginner moose tutorials and the step were they describe going from the weak form too the offdiagjacobian still confuses me. Here is what I have so far:

GrandPotentialSink::computeQpOffDiagJacobian(unsigned int jvar)
{
  const unsigned int cvar = mapJvarToCvar(jvar);

  if (jvar == _v_var)
  {
    Real sum = 0.0;

      sum = _prop_dhmdeta[_qp] * _prop_kiv[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp] * _prop_Rhos[_qp] + _prop_dhmdetai[_qp] * _prop_kxs[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp];

    return _phi[_j][_qp] * sum * _test[_i][_qp];
  }

  Real sum = 0.0;
    sum = _prop_dhmdarg[_qp] * _prop_kiv[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp] * _prop_Rhos[_qp] + _prop_dhmdargi[_qp] * _prop_kxs[_qp] * _prop_Rho[_qp];

  return sum * _phi[_j][_qp];
  
}

Thank you so much for the help, let me know if you need anything else.
And thank you so much for pointing out the Jacobian Testing Tool thats extremely helpful

what are _prop_dhmdarg and _prop_dhmdargi?
which variables are they the derivative with regards to?
and why is jvar not being used to limit this 'return this sum' to the indexes for that variable?
also how do you set _v_var ?

Hello
It s missing this header : JvarMapKernelInterface.h
Does it exist in your version of moose?
Can you find it in either the framework or the modules headers?
Guillaume
Yup that was it, Should have checked that. Thank you so much.

Solve failed and timestep already at dtmin, cannot continue!�[39m

Hello
This happens when the mesh is too deformed.
If the mesh is incorrect to start with:
Use rhe MeshDiagnosticsGenerator with the Jacobian diagnostics.
Report the output here
If there are some errors, then you ll need to fix the mesh
If it s due to the deformation :
Try to set preset = false on any dirichlet bc
Reducing the time step and improving the quality of the mesh can help too
Guillaume

node.title: MOOSE App killed - GPU out of memory - CUDA
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am developing a phase field problem and have noticed that the application crashes at some point due to a memory issue. If I restart the app from the last checkpoint it works fine.
The app works fine if I set it to run less steps.
I assume that the program does not reuse/free the memory allocated on the GPU and stores all steps until the memory runs out.
Has anyone faced this problem and found a way to solve it?
input: input.i.txt
call: mpirun -np 8 --mca pml ucx -x UCX_TLS=sm,cuda_copy,cuda_ipc,cuda -mca btl ^uct ./pf_test-opt -i input.i

node.title: Generating polycrystalline tessellations and running CPFE models
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Is there a possibility in Moose to create polycrystaline structures in the form of tessallations and use that for crystal plasticity simulations? These tessallations would obviously need meshed in a suitable format that Moose understands. I have managed to create the polycrystalline meshes through neper and used that in Moose, but felt would be more convenient if all of them can be done within Moose. Can some one point me to the right set of examples?
Kind regards,
Arun

Hello
I think we don’t have the meshing capability you want here, unless you are willing to define the boundaries of the grains manually.
However we can initialize variables on a regular mesh with a grain pattern. There s the PolyCrystalColoringIC for example
Guillaume
We use neper/dream3d for tessellation then cubit/sculpt for hex mesh. What do you think would be the benefit of having moose native polycrystalline tessellation?
We use this same approach as well for our crystal plasticity simulations. The cubit/sculpt step can be tricky, yet is worth the effort to avoid the "stairstepping" of the mesh at grain boundaries.

I am not sure if Moose based tessellations has any potential advantages over the neper route. Also not very clear how the moose tessellations are handled further to create the mesh. Does moose output any file format that can describe tessellations and related properties?

Hi @hugary1995,

We use neper/dream3d for tessellation then cubit/sculpt for hex mesh. What do you think would be the benefit of having moose native polycrystalline tessellation?

I also want to use neper to create polycrystalline structures for use in moose. Now what I want to ask is, does such an operation require the creation of additional objects in moose? In particular, do you need to create a UserObjects based on PropertyReadFile to manage the Euler angle sequence created by neper ?
You need to read in euler angles one way or the other. If there's no such userobject available in moose, you'll have to write your own.
What file did you export from DREAM3D to import in CUBIT? @hugary1995

node.title: Need help on why making fine mesh throwing off the result from intended one
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am trying to simulate a problem where we apply a some harmonic perodic function [E= E0(sin(wt)) ] (represented by a black solid line on attached figure) and response funcition is a perodic function in nature dP= dP0*sin(wt+theta) which has same frequency as that of applied frequency but with some phase difference (theta).
I choose simulation box of size 18X1X1 nm, but if i choose element size 36X3X3, the profile of reponse function looks what is desired for(Please refer figure attached represent by red solid line). However, increasing mesh resolution with element size 72X3X3, the profile of response completely deviates from the sin profile (Please refer figure attached represent by red dash line).
I used HEX8 for doing this solution.
Now, I have question why increasing element size throwing off my solution from intented solution.
Is it PETSC option or My executioner? I tried to play with Executioner and PETSC options but haven't had a sucess.

I would really appreciate if you guys share your thoughts and insights on this matter.
Thx,
Ashok
This are my precondition and executioner options.
[Preconditioning]
###############################################

Numerical preconditioning/solver options

###############################################
[./smp]
type = SMP
full = true
petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -snes_atol -snes_rtol -ksp_rtol -pc_type  -build_twosided'
petsc_options_value = '    160               1e-10      1e-8      1e-6          bjacobi       allreduce'
[../]
[]
[Executioner]
##########################################

Time integration/solver options

##########################################
type = Transient
solve_type = 'PJFNK'
#scheme = 'crank-nicolson'
dtmin = 1e-16
dt = 0.0001
dtmax = 1e-2
verbose = true
num_steps = 1200
[TimeIntegrator]
type = NewmarkBeta
inactive_tsteps = 1
[]
[]

node.title: Generate a polycrystal structure,  then stop the grain boundary growth and conduct a mechanical stress analysis.
node.bodyText:
Hello, everyone!
I'm planning to generate a polycrystal structure followed the example poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce.i. After generating the polycrystal structure, I intend to stop the grain boundary growth and proceed with additional mechanical stress analyses. Naturally, the Euler angle information (indicating the orientation of the grains) needs to be preserved. And I have some questions needed to address.
1. How can MOOSE stop the GBEvolution at a desired time, and then conduct a pure mechanical stress analysis?
2. How can we utilize BndsCalcIC to define grain boundary blocks and assign special material parameters to the interfacial region in the mechanical stress analysis?
3. If there are any alternative solutions, please do let me know.
I have tried some attempts, but don't find proper method to stop the grain boundary growth. I need the euler angle information of the grains in the mechanical analysis. Thank you!
Best wishes!
Yaode Yin

Here is an attempt by using Control system. But unfortunately, it doesn't work. The grain growth cannot stop.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 20
  ny = 20
  nz = 0
  xmax = 1000
  ymax = 1000
  zmax = 0
  elem_type = QUAD4
  uniform_refine = 2
[]

[GlobalParams]
  op_num = 8
  var_name_base = gr
  grain_num = 36
[]

[Variables]
  [./PolycrystalVariables]
  [../]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./euler_angle_file]
    type = EulerAngleFileReader
    file_name = grn_36_rand_2D.tex
  [../]
  [./voronoi]
    type = PolycrystalVoronoi
    coloring_algorithm = bt
  [../]
  [./grain_tracker]
    type = GrainTrackerElasticity
    threshold = 0.2
    compute_var_to_feature_map = true
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
    flood_entity_type = ELEMENTAL

    C_ijkl = '1.27e5 0.708e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_provider = euler_angle_file
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./PolycrystalICs]
    [./PolycrystalColoringIC]
      polycrystal_ic_uo = voronoi
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./bnds]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain11]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain22]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain12]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./unique_grains]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./var_indices]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./vonmises_stress]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./C1111]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./euler_angle]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./PolycrystalKernel]
  [../]
  [./PolycrystalElasticDrivingForce]
  [../]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./BndsCalc]
    type = BndsCalcAux
    variable = bnds
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain11]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = elastic_strain11
    rank_two_tensor = elastic_strain
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain22]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = elastic_strain22
    rank_two_tensor = elastic_strain
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
  [./elastic_strain12]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = elastic_strain12
    rank_two_tensor = elastic_strain
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 1
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
  [./unique_grains]
    type = FeatureFloodCountAux
    variable = unique_grains
    execute_on = timestep_end
    flood_counter = grain_tracker
    field_display = UNIQUE_REGION
  [../]
  [./var_indices]
    type = FeatureFloodCountAux
    variable = var_indices
    execute_on = timestep_end
    flood_counter = grain_tracker
    field_display = VARIABLE_COLORING
  [../]
  [./C1111]
    type = RankFourAux
    variable = C1111
    rank_four_tensor = elasticity_tensor
    index_l = 0
    index_j = 0
    index_k = 0
    index_i = 0
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
  [./vonmises_stress]

Hello
I can see several options. You could:
Change the equations after the desired time by

adding a time derivative with a very very high coefficient that prevents any change in the solution
use the control system to turn off kernels for the variables of interest. Just keep the time derivative kernel that's it

Create a checkpoint and restart with a different set of equations.
This is the best option if the variables are different in the second part of the solve. You do not want to have nonlinear variables that you just want to freeze.
Similarly you can create a multiapp that does the second solve.
The first solve runs to completion, then executed the multiapp on FINAL to perform the second part.
You can transfer fields from the first solve to the second one

You can transfer variables and the outputs of a class of user objects, the spatial user objects.
Functions and material properties have to be converted to variables first before being transferred
If the meshes are the same then yes you can use the MumtiAppCopyTransfer to move the variables.
Will you be using adaptivity? Keeping the meshes the same with adaptivity requires a little bit of care
